title: Festival Point de croix & Broderie - La Maison Rurale de l'Outre-Forêt

last_post.content: @CrowquillGal In #Alsace, Eastern #France: https://www.maison-rurale.fr/point-de-croix/ I'ts a #farm #museum and #CulturalHeritage centre (I volunteer there as a guide and teach in workshops). Our annual International #Embroidery Festival is organised in several villages and a town around the museum. Communal halls, galleries, public spaces, and even churches change into exhibition halls for four days. This year's topic: "At the school of thread". One of our exhibition rooms is a reconstructed old village #school.

I ended up on the man page for 'jot' because I was trying to figure out something ancient, and now I'm worried I'll accidentally summon Cthulhu by combining the examples...

https://man.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?jot(1)

Specifically:

and the strings xaa through xaz with: jot -w xa%c 26 a

while 20 random 8-letter strings are produced with: jot -r -c 160 a z | rs -g 0 8

Infinitely many yes's may be obtained through: jot -b yes 0

Breath fairly taken away by this note at the end of Washington Post article illustrating with 3D models the destruction caused by an AR-15’s bullets.

It’s not just theoretical. With autopsy reports and family consent, they use those 3D models to show us how Dylan Pozner (6) and Peter Wang (15) were killed. Thoughts and prayers can fuck themselves.

title: Tidally Heated Exomoons around $ε$ Eridani b: Observability and prospects for characterization

last_post.content: Can we image tidally heated exomoons using JWST? Probably! This is a new paper by graduate student Elina Kleisioti who is working with me and Dominic Dirkx from TU Delft - she simulated internal models for exomoons around Eps Eri b, a gas giant exoplanet around a very nearby star. https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03410 "Tidally Heated Exomoons around ε Eridani b: Observability and prospects for characterization" /1 🧵

In our latest podcast episode of @NulliusInVerba we reflect on how knowledge generation is facilitated or hindered by top down regulation. Should researchers self-organize, or be directed by for example science funders? Where can the current way things are organized be improved? https://www.podbean.com/media/share/pb-xmg3u-13f54bd?utm_campaign=embed_player_share&utm_medium=dlink&utm_source=embed_player

It sounds trivial and obvious, but are you reading error bars correctly?

Do you know whether you're looking at standard errors (measures of inferential uncertainty), standard deviations (measures of spread of individual observations), or 95% confidence intervals around the mean?

And are your intuitions correct about how to interpret each of these?

Here's a nice primer, refresher, or teaching article.

https://www.nature.com/articles/nmeth.2659

h/t @jakehofman

Great to see that OpenAlex by OurrResarch is now also human readable in courageous alpha-version (so with bugs but allowing early input) here: https://alpha.openalex.org/works. This open source scholarly knowledge graph uses a.o. PIDs to connect works/authors/institutions/sources/concepts and more.

title: 6 reasons tooltips are a bad idea and what to do instead

last_post.content:
6 reasons tooltips are a bad idea and what to do instead (by Adam Silver): https://adamsilver.io/blog/6-reasons-tooltips-are-a-bad-idea-and-what-to-do-instead/
In the context of forms, I tend to agree here, show the hint directly instead of hiding it.
Unfortunately, sometimes the help is too long (hello enterprise forms). But, if you can't avoid tooltips, I recommend checking this to make them accessible: https://sarahmhigley.com/writing/tooltips-in-wcag-21/ (by Sarah Higley)
#Form #UX

Graphs of the sizes of fediverse instances, how common they are, and where the most people are! 🧵

Data pulled from https://instances.social/ (by @TheKinrar) and excludes pawoo and baraag as they're heavily blocked for good reasons (it seems)

Breaking down instances by the number of users into bins (that are quasi human friendly logarithmic), we see that the majority (55%) have 2-50 users, ~33% have 1 user, and almost all instances have less than 5,000 users.

This weekend feels like a turning point for me. I didn't get a ton of "coding" done - but I kinda did. I also didn't get much done planning for my Denweaver game/app but I did get a start.

I got a Godot engine project started, and I got a few milestones done. I also set up the code src at Codeberg - which feels like a real substantial start. I can use this site to manage my project and share it with the world. It even works great with VSCode ...

I feel like if this is a journey of a thousand steps - that I made a good first step this weekend.

title: Overshoot: Why It’s Already Too Late To Save Civilization

last_post.content:
If you're a follower of mine, then you're likely not very optimistic about where we're headed. You can see what's going on, our social fabric rapidly deteriorating, the climate breaking down, our ecosystem pushed to the brink.

But unless you've dug deep into the underlying problems eating away at the foundations of modern industrial society, you may not recognize how truly precarious our situation is.

If you're ready to face the bad news — the very worst news — I'll recommend a long article bringing together all the factors and laying out the many reasons, backed up by research, that explain why we're racing toward collapse.

It's grim reading and yet, for me at least, once I learn what's actually happening, I feel better prepared and more motivated to take appropriate action.
________________________

"Overshoot: Why It’s Already Too Late To Save Civilization"

https://medium.com/@CollapseSurvival/overshoot-why-its-already-too-late-to-save-civilization-e834cb4ec694

#Environment #Climate #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #Collapse

title: Copper scarcity will not materially slow down the energy transition - NEON Research

last_post.content:
"Many scientific publications assert copper scarcity is a roadblock on the way to renewable energy, but almost none take substitution into account. Although copper demand could increase about 30% because the transition to renewable energy, substitution with aluminum is possible for almost all applications. Therefore, it is implausible that copper scarcity will hamper the transition to renewable energy.'

https://neonresearch.nl/copper-scarcity-will-not-materially-slow-down-the-energy-transition/

A lot of meta going around about the use of defederation recently, so let me chime in a little. Firstly:

Defederate the fash and harassers early and often. There's absolutely no reason to put up with them
Who small, friend-group instances choose to federate with is up to them. When you have 5 users, you're pretty much accountable only to them and it's easy to be accountable to them

With that out of the way, the complicated area where nobody can really agree on really lies in the middle. As an example, the people who threatened Matt Blaze's instance with defederation for criticising Mastodon's DM system didn't have some trust and safety issue in mind; they just had a beef. (And I don't think that one was serious, or would travel very far, but wielding it as a weapon like that is a rather ridiculous escalation from whoever was responsible for doing so)

@mekkaokereke used the term "HOA-style racism" to describe it, and I very much buy into that. An instance with a bunch of "just asking questions" sealions will putter along under the radar alienating users, while saying something that makes someone uncomfortable will get you yeeted into the sun.

There's a distinction between safety and comfort; and I feel like some of the moderation here conflates them. That's not to say that there's no purpose in making your place comfortable, but the two are not the same thing. People typically acknowledge that black people talking about racism is often unfomfortable but not unsafe, but I think theres a lot of other ares where people haven't.

As a tool for achieving safety (and complying with local laws...), the ability to cut all communication with another instance is vital. As a tool for achieving comfort, it's an overly blunt one.

(And also, it should go without saying: if your users are dogpiling someone, get them to cut that shit out)

title: Inside the fight to save a beleaguered butterfly

last_post.content:
Ben Goldfarb's latest piece in High Country News on the desperate struggle to keep a northern California butterfly species alive is a great read. Species recovery is a hard and thankless enough job with the most charismatic mammal - for insects, it's the same work, backwards and in heels, for less money. The people who do it deserve more features like this. https://www.hcn.org/issues/55.5/south-endangered-species-inside-the-fight-to-save-a-beleaguered-butterfly

#ecology #insects #EndangeredSpecies #butterflies #Lepidoptodon #IsThatAThing #ThatShouldBeAThing
